<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_bus_close:
```c
static void metal_linux_bus_close(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		if (ldrv->sdrv)
			sysfs_close_driver(ldrv->sdrv);
		ldrv->sdrv = NULL;
	}

	sysfs_close_bus(lbus->sbus);
	lbus->sbus = NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_bus_close:
static struct linux_bus *to_linux_bus(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	return metal_container_of(bus, struct linux_bus, bus);
}
...
static int metal_linux_probe_bus(struct linux_bus *lbus)
{
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;
	int ret, error = -ENODEV;

	lbus->sbus = sysfs_open_bus(lbus->bus_name);
	if (!lbus->sbus)
		return -ENODEV;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		ret = metal_linux_probe_driver(lbus, ldrv);
		/* Clear the error if any driver is available */
		if (!ret)
			error = ret;
	}

	if (error) {
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);
		return error;
	}

	error = metal_linux_register_bus(lbus);
	if (error)
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);

	return error;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected fragments that contain inter-function calls and therefore could participate in direct or indirect recursion: the full metal_linux_bus_close implementation (which calls sysfs_close_driver and sysfs_close_bus and iterates drivers), the driver probe loop (which calls metal_linux_probe_driver), and the places where metal_linux_probe_bus calls metal_linux_bus_close (both error paths), plus the call to metal_linux_register_bus (since that registration step could invoke callbacks found elsewhere). These fragments should be investigated to determine whether any of the called functions (sysfs_close_bus, sysfs_close_driver, metal_linux_probe_driver, metal_linux_register_bus, etc.) call back into metal_linux_bus_close or metal_linux_probe_bus, producing indirect recursion.

Fragments not selected and why they need not be investigated:
- to_linux_bus and its use of metal_container_of: this is a simple container_of wrapper that performs no function calls that could create recursion.
- Local variable declarations and pointer NULL assignments (e.g., ldrv->sdrv = NULL; lbus->sbus = NULL): these are simple assignments and cannot cause function calls/recursion.
- Any code not shown in the provided snippets: cannot be assessed here; investigation should focus on the listed call sites.
